questions.text: An old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells, and culture on MacConkey agar showed the following. Which organism is involved here?
questions.solution:
This patient who presented with dysuria and frequent micturition with urinalysis showing pus cells, and growth of lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar suggests a diagnosis of urinary tract infection by Escherichia coli. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as:

  • Lactose fermenters - Escherichia, Klebsiella
  • Late lactose fermenters - Shigella sonnei
  • Non-lactose fermenters- Salmonella species, Shigella species

The image below shows lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Mnemonic to remember non-lactose fermenters: (SPY PSM)

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia- late fermenter
  • Shigella (except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

questions.text:
The stool culture of a patient with suspected food poisoning produced hemolytic colonies on blood agar. The isolated organism gave a positive indole test and a positive MUG test. You observe the following colonies on eosin methylene blue agar. Identify the organism.

MUG - 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with suspected food poisoning with stool culture growing hemolytic colony on blood agar with a positive indole test and MUG test with a iridescent green colony growth on eosin methylene blue agar is characteristic of Escherichia coli. 

E. coli produces the enzyme β-glucuronidase which is tested using the MUG test. In it, the substrate MUG (4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide) is reduced by the enzyme to produce a fluorescent color which indicates a positive MUG test.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: What is the cut-off for bacteriuria beyond which a diagnosis of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) can be made?
questions.solution:
The cut-off value for bacteriuria to diagnose catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) is >103 CFU/mL.

The minimum criterion for catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-ASB) is >102 CFU/mL.

Related Pearl: Asymptomatic bacteriuria

 
Asymptomatic bacteriuria: Urinary tract infection without any symptoms. Criteria for diagnosis are as follows:
 
Type of specimen Number of samples required  Minimum colony-forming units (cfu)/mL required for diagnosis of UTI
Midstream clean-catch urine specimen

For women: 2 consecutive samples

For men: single sample

 1,00,000 of the same bacterial species 
Catheterized urine specimen  Single sample

100 for asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-ASB)

1000 for catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CA-UTI)
Suprapubic aspirate Single sample Any growth of microorganisms in the culture

questions.text: A tourist came to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. Which of the following strains of E. coli is most commonly implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient with watery diarrhea most likely has traveller’s diarrhea caused by Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). 

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism that causes diarrhea in travelers. It produces the following toxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin) - acts by ↑cAMP
  • ST (heat-stable toxin) - two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
    • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑ cGMP in the intestine.
    • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

Other options: 

Option A: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using E. coli adherent factor (EAF) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) and causes effacement of microvilli. 

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.

Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, which can be detected as a diagnostic test. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Identify the organism below that causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
questions.solution:
Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.

The image below shows an electron microscopy image of E Coli.

questions.text: You are investigating an outbreak of diarrhea.  You find out that the etiological agent causes stacked-brick formation on hep-2 cells as shown below.  What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The stacked-brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells is caused by enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC).

Enteroaggregative E. coli has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF). EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) is considered to be a major virulence factor for EAEC.

The given image shows the stacked-brick pattern of adherence on microscopy at 600x magnification.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. She was diagnosed with hemolytic uremic syndrome and treated with plasmapheresis and dialysis. What is false about the infectious causative agent?

choices.text: It does not produce a Shiga like toxin
There is person to person transmission.

questions.solution:
Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) serotype O157:H7. It produces a Shiga like toxin, therefore EHEC is also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC).

Other options:

Option A - Strains of E. coli producing verocytotoxin or Shiga toxin (stx2a-g) can cause diarrheal disease ranging from mild diarrhea to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and HUS. The most common EHEC belongs to serotype O157:H7.

Option C - In EHEC diarrhea, fecal leukocytes are commonly seen (70%) but although it is an infectious condition, fever is not seen. The absence of fever can lead to its misdiagnosis as a non-infectious condition such as intussusception or ischemic bowel disease.

Option D - The disease is transmitted through contaminated feces. Person-to-person transmission can occur if infected persons do not wash their hands after using the toilet or after changing diapers.

Note: Shiga toxin produced by S. dysenteriae is referred to as Stx.

questions.text: Sereny test was employed for laboratory diagnosis of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The Sereny test is an animal pathogenicity test that used to be employed for laboratory diagnosis of enteroinvasive E. coli and Shigella.

Freshly isolated suspension of bacteria is instilled into the eyes of guinea pigs which leads to mucopurulent conjunctivitis and severe keratitis.

It is not in use anymore as we have better methods of detecting toxigenicity now like molecular methods.

questions.text: What is the culture media used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli?

choices.text: Thiosulphate citrate Bile salt sucrose medium

questions.solution:
Sorbitol-MacConkey agar is used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli.

E. coli O157:H7 does not ferment sorbitol and produces pale colonies on Sorbitol-MacConkey agar. All other strains of E. coli ferment sorbitol. Thus they produce pink colonies on Sorbitol-MacConkey agar.

O157:H7 strains do not contain β-glucuronidase and so are unable to use the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide(MUG). Thus, they give a negative MUG test.

questions.text:
Match the following E.coli with their respective pathogenesis.
E. coli Mechanism of action
1. ETEC A. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase
2. EIEC B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells
3. EHEC C. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells
4. EPEC D. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

E. coli Mechanism of action
1. ETEC A. Produce a heat-stable toxin and cause activation of guanylyl cyclase
2. EIEC B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells  
3. EHEC C. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells
4. EPEC D. Adhere to the mucosal surface and cause effacement of microvilli

The various strains of Escherichia coli are:

  • Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism that causes diarrhea in travelers. It produces the following toxins:
    • LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
    • ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
      • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
      • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.
  • Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) invade interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and cause a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, detection of which can also be a diagnostic test. Sereny's test was employed to diagnose EIEC but it is not in use anymore.
  • Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  • Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of small intestine using EAF and LEE and causes effacement of microvilli. This leads to attachment and effacement lesions of intestinal cells.
  • Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: E.coli is an aerobe and facultative anaerobe.
Proteus infection increases risk of uric acid stones.
E.coli is motile by peritrichous flagella.
Proteus can metabolise phenylalanine to phenylpyruvic acid.

questions.solution:
Proteus increases the risk of struvite stones in the bladder as it leads to the alkalinisation of urine. Struvite stones are magnesium-ammonium phosphate stones that appear as rectangular/coffin-lid crystals shaped on urine microscopy. Uric acid stones are precipitated in acidic urine.

Proteus produces enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. This property is the basis for the phenylalanine deaminase test.

The test is performed by inoculating the organism in phenylalanine agar. After incubation, 10% ferric chloride is added to the media. If phenyl pyruvic acid was produced, it will react with the ferric chloride and turn dark green.  If the medium remains a straw colour, the organism is negative for phenylalanine deaminase production.

E. coli is an aerobe and facultative anaerobe. Its motility is due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is the most common cause of urinary tract infections.

questions.text: Which of the following shows Dienes phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Dienes phenomenon is exhibited by Proteus mirabilis.

When two identical strains of Proteus are inoculated at different places of the same culture plate, the resulting swarms of growth coalesce and no line is formed between swarming cultures of the same strain. However, if they are from two different strains, the spreading films of growth fail to coalesce and remain separated by a narrow but easily visible furrow (known as Dienes line). This is known as Dienes phenomenon.

The image below shows Dienes phenomenon.

questions.text: Blood culture of the sputum sample taken from a patient diagnosed with hospital-acquired pneumonia, showed a characteristic phenomenon as shown in the image. Identify the bacteria that exhibit this phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given image of the blood culture finding shows the characteristic bull's eye swarming pattern exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively with the help of peritrichous flagella, resulting in swarming on solid media. It can be suppressed by the addition of:

  • phenyl ethyl alcohol
  • chloral hydrate
  • sulphonamides
  • sodium azide
  • boric acid
  • increasing the concentration of agar to 6%.

Swarming does not occur on MacConkey medium and cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium.

Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones. P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. 

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

questions.text: A middle-aged man from north India presents with a deformity as shown in the image below. He gives a history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge before this nodule appeared. Which of the following organisms is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above image and clinical scenario are suggestive of rhinoscleroma and it is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

K. rhinoscleromatis is a gram-negative bacillus also known as Frisch bacillus. It is endemic in north India. Rhinoscleroma is characterized by chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of the nose. Biopsy of the lesion shows:

  • Mikulicz cells- large foamy cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated, cytoplasm containing causative bacilli.
  • Russell bodies- eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. These are also observed in multiple myeloma.

Other options:  

Option A: Rhinosporidium seeberi causes rhinosporidiosis.

Option C: K. ozaenae causes atrophic rhinitis.

Option D: K. oxytoca is associated with hemorrhagic colitis.

questions.text: You notice a sputum sample of a patient suspected of having ventilator-associated pneumonia turns progressively redder over time. Microscopic examination of the sample reveals an absence of red blood cells. Which of the following organisms could have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given condition of sputum sample turning redder over time can be caused by Serratia marcescens.

Serratia marcescens are pleomorphic coccobacilli that can grow in sputum after collection and can mimic hemoptysis because they produce a red pigment called prodigiosin.

S. macescens mainly cause healthcare-associated infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, meningitis, endocarditis, septicemia and peritonitis. They can contaminate IV fluids, surgical instruments, and antiseptic solutions.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with a single painless papule on his penis with no enlarged lymph nodes. A smear was made from the lesion and stained with Wright- Giemsa stain which showed the finding as shown in the following picture. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells (called Pund cells).

Klebsiella granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a safety pin appearance.

Bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) is shown by:

  • H. ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Burkholderia mallei

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline
